page.title: 07GEOLOGY OF LITTLE BADDOW
page.content: The underlying solid geology of the Baddow region is London clay with overlying Quaternary and Alluvial deposits. Baddow is bounded by the Chelmer flood plain and hilly clay relief. The Chelmer river has produced two terraces by fluvial erosion. These are composed of fine silts which have been deposited by tthe meandering path of the river. The clay relief is the result of a great amount of deposition during the Ecocene period and as a result of minor earth movement an undulating landscape has developed. Quaternary deposits from British glacial movements of the last 400 years can be found here, especially evident are sands and gravels from the outwash plains of the Anglian and Devensian glaciations. Some of these deposits have been slightly eroded by weathering action.
